review.title: Bayesian Poisson Tucker Decomposition for Learning the Structure of International Relations
review.abstract: We introduce Bayesian Poisson Tucker decomposition (BPTD) for modeling country--country interaction event data. These data consist of interaction events of the form "country $i$ took action $a$ toward country $j$ at time $t$." BPTD discovers overlapping country--community memberships, including the number of latent communities. In addition, it discovers directed community--community interaction networks that are specific to "topics" of action types and temporal "regimes." We show that BPTD yields an efficient MCMC inference algorithm and achieves better predictive performance than related models. We also demonstrate that it discovers interpretable latent structure that agrees with our knowledge of international relations.
histories: To appear in Proceedings of the 33rd International Conference on Machine Learning (ICML 2016)
review.COMMENTS: To appear in Proceedings of the 33rd International Conference on Machine Learning (ICML 2016)

sections.heading: 4. Posterior Inference
sections.text: Given an observed count tensor Y, inference in BPTD involves the "reversal" of the generative process to obtain the posterior distribution over the parameters based on Y and hyperparameters. Posterior distribution is analytically intractable, but we can approximate it using a set of posterior samples. We subtract these samples using Gamma-Poisson conjugacy and the auxiliary variable techniques of Zhou & Carin (2012). We offer the conditional posteriors in the complementary material.Conditional posteriors depend on Y via a number of "latent sources" (Cemgil, 2009) or subcounts.

sections.heading: 5. Country–Country Interaction Event Data
sections.text: Our data comes from the Integrated Crisis Early Warning System (ICEWS) by Boschee et al. and the Global Database of Events, Language, and Tone (GDELT) by Leetaru & Schrodt (2013).Both ICEWS and GDELT use the hierarchy of conflict and mediation events (CAMEO) for senders, recipients, and actions; the top level of CAMEO encoding for senders and recipients is their affiliation with countries, while lower levels in the hierarchy take into account more specific attributes such as their sectors (e.g. government or civil society) and their religious or ethnic affiliations.When investigating international relations using CAMEO-encoded event data, researchers usually look only at the countries of senders and recipients. There are 249 countries represented in ICEWS that include non-universally recognized states, such as occupied Palestinian squares and former states.

sections.heading: 7. Exploratory Analysis
sections.text: We used a tensor of the ICEWS events of 1995-2000, with monthly increments of time, to explore the latent structure discovered by BPTD. We initially left C = 50, K = 8 and R = 3 - i.e., C · C · K · R = 60,000 latent classes - and used the shrinkage of Prior to adaptively learn the most appropriate numbers of communities, themes and regimes. We found C = 20 communities and K = 6 subjects with weights significantly greater than zero. We offer an act of community weights in the complementary material. Although all three regimes did not have zero weights, one had a much greater weight than the other two. For comparison, Schein et al. (2015) used fifty latent classes to model the same data, while Hoff (2015) used C = 4, K = 4, and R = 4 to model a similar tensor of GDELT.Topics of the shareholder types.

sections.heading: 8. Summary
sections.text: Unlike previous models, BPTD uses all three representations of an interactive event dataset: 1) a set of event markers, 2) an event-type tensor, and 3) a set of weighted multinet snapshots. BPTD uses a poissonlikelihood model that respects the discrete nature of the data and its inherent sparseness. In addition, BPTD provides a compositional algorithm that is more efficient than non-compositional algorithms for allocation. Since BPTD is a tucker decomposition model, it splits parameters across latent classes. BPTD decomposition models force each latent class to capture potentially redundant information. BPTD "more with this decomposition structure that we reflect well in our interpretation structure."

Infinite relational models: The infinite relational model (IRM) of Kemp et al. (2006) also learns latent structure specific to each dimension of an M -dimensional tensor; however, unlike BPTD, the elements of this tensor are binary, indicating the presence or absence of the corresponding event type. The IRM therefore uses a Bernoulli likelihood. metadata.abstractText: We introduce Bayesian Poisson Tucker decomposition (BPTD) for modeling country– country interaction event data. These data consist of interaction events of the form “country i took action a toward country j at time t.” BPTD discovers overlapping country– community memberships, including the number of latent communities. In addition, it discovers directed community–community interaction networks that are specific to “topics” of action types and temporal “regimes.” We show that BPTD yields an efficient MCMC inference algorithm and achieves better predictive performance than related models. We also demonstrate that it discovers interpretable latent structure that agrees with our knowledge of international relations.
